awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Transforming STEM Undergraduate Education through Academic Literacy, Mentoring, and Professional Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) will advance the aims of the HSI Program by  developing new curricula and methods of instruction that increase student persistence and success.  The project will implement a faculty development framework that helps faculty: 1) connect their course content to students' background knowledge; 2) demonstrate connections between lower level and upper level courses; and 3) help students develop professional identities that can lead them into STEM careers.  The project will focus on developing students' ability to understand the complex language of science, including words and visual representations, such as graphs, charts, and diagrams.  Expected outcomes are that faculty will develop expertise in innovative, evidence-based teaching approaches that enhance student learning, and that students will develop marketable skills needed for success in STEM careers.  

The overall goal of this project is to develop new methods of instruction and associated curricular change with an explicit focus on the intersection of academic literacy and content competencies.  This goal will be achieved through the application of evidence-based teaching approaches, coaching of STEM faculty to improve student learning, and by providing student mentoring and professional development experiences.  The project includes the following specific tasks: 1) Developing and improving undergraduate STEM students' integrated understanding of academic literacy and core competencies; 2) Creating interdisciplinary professional development lesson study groups of instructors to engage in sustainable instructional and curricular change; 3) Aligning STEM curricula between lower and upper division courses; 4) Developing a near-peer mentoring program for sophomore and junior level STEM students; 5) Providing research opportunities and professional development activities for STEM students; and 6) Evaluating the relevance and effectiveness of the institutional curricular redesign.  These proposed activities focus on the critical transition between lower and upper level undergraduate courses, a key transition for student retention and graduation in STEM.  In addition, innovative cross-disciplinary partnerships will be established between collaborating STEM and Education faculty.  These partnerships will create lesson study groups of instructors that draw explicit attention to the role of academic literacy in the development of strong university-level STEM teaching and learning.  The proposed plan builds on the dedication of UTSA to increasing diversity in the STEM workforce.  This plan is an integrated approach to increase the number of undergraduate underrepresented minorities who graduate from the UTSA Colleges of Engineering and Sciences.  It is expected that the program will benefit STEM undergraduates at UTSA by increasing their retention rates, critical thinking skills, professional knowledge, self-efficacy, graduation rates, and professional and workforce preparedness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Overview  

The Transforming STEM Undergraduate Education initiative aimed to support the experiences and outcomes of Hispanic students and all STEM students at UTSA through the restructuring of critical courses, implementing a peer mentoring program, and providing opportunities to participate in an undergraduate research program. Using the Language and Literacy in STEM (LA-STEM) framework, the initiative restructured five lower and upper-division undergraduate courses in the Colleges of Engineering and Sciences. In addition, the project provided a near-peer mentoring program and research opportunities for undergraduate students in the College of Engineering aimed at fostering a sense of belonging and student success.  

Key Accomplishments  

The course redesign and professional development implementation resulted in eleven faculty participating in six semesters of Lesson Study, an instructional professional development model, and redesigned 19 target lessons aimed at improving student learning from spring 2019 to spring 2022. Faculty engaged in improving lessons through focused attention to STEM/academic literacy, creating opportunities for student interaction, and orientations to student learning with high to moderate fidelity. The faculty reported improved instructional methods, shifts in their perspectives to teaching, and improved student understanding of concepts. The course redesign component of the grant led to the curricular alignment of lower-and-upper division courses and a change in the complexity of navigating engineering program curriculum. 

The overarching goal of the project was to improve student learning, persistence, and graduation in STEM majors. Key findings include students who participated in a redesigned engineering course were more likely to remain in their STEM major (72%) and be in good academic standing (88%) (Vasquez Cano & Yin, 2023). Hispanic students held positive views about their experiences in redesigned courses and reported an increased ability to complete LA-STEM related tasks including solving word problems (89%) and explaining graphs (88%) (Vasquez Cano, 2022). In the sciences lower-division course, Hispanic and low-income students had a 90% passing rate. Data from the peer mentoring showed a 19% increase in undergraduate student participation from spring 2020 to spring 2022. 

Intellectual Merit 

This project provided evidence for sustained Lesson Study in the higher education context, setting the stage for future studies on advancing professional development and improving student learning in STEM. The LA-STEM framework we established can be used as a model for focusing on academic language and literacy and student learning in STEM contexts. This work achieved the primary goal of developing and improving STEM students' understanding of academic literacy and core competencies through the restructuring of courses and faculty professional development. Our findings were presented at national conferences, facilitating knowledge dissemination. Faculty continuous engagement in Lesson Study activities highlights the value of a professional learning community in higher education STEM contexts.  

Broader Impacts 

The project developed opportunities for engineering and science faculty to build a professional learning community that fostered dialogue, engagement, and commitment to supporting student success. The curriculum materials developed as part of the lesson study cycles were shared and adopted by engineering faculty and teaching assistants. In terms of student success, this project aimed to directly support student learning. Survey data indicated students reported increased ability to complete disciplinary specific tasks and felt better prepared for upper-division level courses. The established framework has the potential to be used in other STEM disciplines to improve student learning which could have a positive impact on developing skilled engineers and scientists for the workforce.
